div1.head: Recollections of Yellow Fever Epidemic, by Mrs. Tyler, March 31, 1914
div1.p:
Yellow Fever
A
Norfolk Va 31 III 1914

Mrs. Tyler 90 yrs. old.
Maiden name Rogers
Dr. Earle's mother-in-law
descendant of Fr refugees on San Domingo-Perier
vessels from Fr ports but ylo for to Norfolk in
1855 vessel was not quarantined, was previous
habit to quarantine all ships. This was first ship & so
let in.
First person w YF young man named Kent
employed at navy yd. Kent taken sick from was a clerk who
was on board often & took yf & died
in first wk many new cases developed
as [?] 30 people were buried
in mo. August

Mr Earle's mammy explained that
her mo & father died in boat bkg it
brought olives in keps in ylo fever
Mr Tyler was fat if Dr Higgins
whose wife had gone S to escape
Dr H promised not to leave her &
was taken w fever in her bed room
& in less than 2 d he was dead.
Doctors scarce mostly from cites
where had ladies Savannah
Shreveport N.O. Charleston
2
Dr. Ravanel from Charleston attended
Mr Tyler and then whole epidemic
& leave after we accept no pay
even for those who can afford it
Lasted until 1st post Oct 5th when
was great jubilation

Mr Jackson St Paul'sch.. (See [?] written)
was in sick room w Dr. Higgins & in less
than a wk both buried.

People died so quickly & not bury &
sometimes 6 & 8 coffins deep and and cemetery
wall.

Men went abt in night in carts
crying bring out dead,

Mr. Tyler was there at whole if it & and
attend to sick & put them in boxes or
coffins or if those not available he'd
wrap up & put them in rooms
Did not take his but afterward
taken in new attack

Temporary hospitals where men wd commit
watches & money to his care for refugee families
3
all banks closed

One man with Mr T wd go to Lexton he wd dr
I have so many I am going to lump here & there
wd see rows of wagons waiting with their dead.
Balt did not help, stopt all communication
& stopt boats. Still remembered in Norfolk
Phila even sent ice & liquor & med
& food. No epidemic in Phila.

This was second visit of yf to N first in 1823
that was not so bad.

The doctors died at first & some at bedsides
their stars are at Peter grove & Sherwood
cemeteries in Norfolk

Periers have lot in Elwood
Mr Rogers & Mr Tyler fur in ...

Robbery by professed nurses but not much
debauchery

People got so frightened they left in drovs
R R not allowed to go or boats
not allowed to go to Richmond.

Mr T had typhoid after y f. & then
lost his mind fr Sep 6 until Feb 1856
4
It was so cold that they skated from Norfolk
to Old Point & built booths on ice
never so cold before or since.
Churches all closed.

mallery's
3 girls blfl & get bells in N neighbors of Miss Rogers
who saw them on Aunt & Uncle who demonstrated
on their going to public assembly they sd we cd
not go to a better place

In one wk mother & & 3 daughters all died
Mr Tyler buried them all.

They hd servant who came tol me & told Mr T
the mother was ill Mr T went & sent Dr. Selden who attended
then. Mr. T thinks Dr Henry Selden
died of fever

Amanda who lives w Mrs Ella Wood
remembers epidemic

Father' O'Keefe Irish man was a ministering angel
in Epidemic. lived to good old age.
See monument in Catholic cemetory?
He was good alike to Catholics & Protestants
looked out for children after death parents

Mr Jackson (Rev) commenced a bk but T
Mrs Roger was last person he visited.

Drs Henry & Wm Selden
Drs came down fr Phila to help & died
a lot set aside for phys who died
of fever.

Sun hardly ever shone brilliant during fever
epidemic wd set like ball time haze like
Indian Summer all days. No bright
sunshine whole time.
